Award.AwardTitle: Retrievable and Reusable Nanoparticle-Pinched Polymer Brushes Enable Highly Efficient Microalgae Dewatering for Cost-Effective Biofuel Production

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1160291
Liang

Various analyses based on the production rate and environmental considerations have suggested that biofuels from microalgae are likely the only realistic substitute capable of releasing our reliance on fossil fuels. Despite decades of effort, commercial production of microalgae-derived biofuels has not emerged because current technologies for microalgae dewatering add a huge cost to the final product, and present a major barrier between algaculture and biofuels.

A knowledge gap exists in the underlying principles governing microalgae dewatering, particularly for the rational design of coagulation agents. The long-term goal of the proposed work is to understand the underlying principles that govern the stability of a colloidal suspension of living cells, and to direct the phase separation of free-floating cells in a controllable fashion. The overall objective of this proposal is to identify the rational correlations between inter-algal pair interactions and coagulation-agent structures in order to achieve highly efficient microalgae dewatering at a negligible cost. The central hypothesis is that nanoparticle-pinched polymer brushes, i.e., radiating polymer chains covalently bonded to a nanoparticulate core, are far more effective in dewatering microalgae than conventional flocculants; in addition, using solid-state nanoparticles allows low-cost operations (e.g., using magnetic fields) to be designed to collect algal biomass and retrieve the coagulation agents for multiple cycles of microalgae dewatering, which further reduces the operational cost significantly. We have formulated this hypothesis based on our strongly supportive preliminary data. The rationale underlying the proposed research is that, once the structural characteristics responsible for the unusually high performance of this novel coagulation agent are understood, precise control of its structure is expected to enable unprecedentedly cost-effective microalgae dewatering. Hence the bottleneck preventing commercialization of microalgae-derived biofuels will be cleared. We plan to test our central hypothesis and accomplish the overall objective of this application by pursuing the following three specific aims: 1. Identify a facile and highly efficient approach to synthesize paramagnetic nanoparticle-pinched polymer brushes with well-defined structures; 2. Determine how the microalgae dewatering efficiency is regulated by the structural characteristics of the coagulation agents; 3. Determine the efficiency of retrieving nanoparticle-pinched polymer brushes for continuous cycles of microalgae growth and dewatering. The expected contribution of this work is to determine the structural characteristics of engineered coagulation agents that endow them with an unusually high efficiency in microalgae dewatering and an unusually low operational cost. This contribution is significant, because it creates a class of super coagulation agents via examining rational correlations between inter-algal pair interactions and flocculants of well-defined structures. This aspect has been poorly understood despite decades of relentless trial-and-error experiments with commercially available chemicals.

Energy and environment represent the top challenges for the sustainable development of our societies. It is well understood that securing renewable energy sources is the grand challenge of our time, but it is not always recognized that any engineered material proposed to address that challenge must be sustainable itself, an example is the design of microalgae coagulation agent in this application. The researchers plan to bring broad societal awareness on this aspect with the following integrated activities: Incorporating research into teaching. The assembled research team will be a nucleus to enhance biofuel research at Mines by giving seminars, developing course materials, and attracting industry sponsorship. The PI will build a webpage devoted to microalgae harvesting issues, and disseminate the video clips of microalgae dewatering experiments to Youtube to advertise sustainable materials for sustainable energy; Outreach to Underrepresented Groups. The researchers plan to build a focused and sustainable outreach program by developing lecture materials and classroom demonstration experiments on algal biofuels, which will be used by the PI and his graduate students, to participate in an existing outreach program at Mines that spans grades kindergarten through the twelfth in two school districts, Adams County District 50 (AC50) and Meeker County (MC). Both school districts are rurally located and have a high proportion of students who are living in poverty

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fossil fuels provide nearly two-thirds of the electricity and virtually all of the transportation fuels in USA. It is well known that continued reliance on fossil fuel is unsustainable because of their depleting supplies and the alarming accumulation of greenhouse gases due to their consumption. Microalgae-derived biofuels have been actively pursued as renewable and carbon neutral fuels for decades. Since the Department of Energy’s landmark Aquatic Species Program in 1978, enormous progress has been made on algal species collection, metabolic engineering, algaculture module development, and conversion of algal biomass into biofuels. However, technology for microalgae dewatering, i.e., the separation of algal cells from their dilute growth medium (~ 0.01-0.1wt%), remains essentially the same as what was known 40 years before. Commercial production of microalgae-derived biofuels has not emerged because current technologies for microalgae dewatering add a huge cost and present a major bottleneck to algae-based fuels.

This work supported by NSF (Federal Award ID: 1623240) aims to understand the underlying principles governing microalgae dewatering for the rational design of coagulation agents that can direct spontaneous microalgae coagulation, allow cost-effective retrieval of coagulated algae biomass, and open the possibility to recycle the coagulation agent to be reused for multiple cycles of microalgae dewatering operations, which further reduces the operational cost and environmental footprint. We designed and successfully developed a novel family of microalgae coagulant called nanoparticle-pinched polymer brushes (NPPBs), i.e. nanoscale "hairy balls" comprised of individual paramagnetic nanoparticles (1 nanometer is about one ten thousandth of the width of a human hair) decorated with a fuzzy layer of polymer brushes covalently grafted on their surface. These nanoscale "hairy balls" are chemically stable and dissolve readily in water. In the presence of microalgae, they spontaneously adhere to algal cells like "glues", resulting the formation of large algal flocs that precipitate out from the growth media rapidly. The dewatered algal flocs can be easily harvested under magnetic field. We have determined how the microalgae dewatering efficiency is regulated by the structural characteristics of the coagulation agents both experimentally and "in silico" by developing a self-consistent field theory for computer simulations. Finally, we have determined that after algal oil extraction (by organic solvents) and residue biomass removal (by ionic liquids), the NPPBs maintain their structural integrity and can be re-used for multiple cycles of microalgae dewatering. It should be noted that the NPPBs do not contaminate algal growth media for continuous cycles of algal growth, the do not complicate downstream algal fuel processing because they can be readily separated from the coagulated algal biomass. The results from this study open a road map to optimize the design of NPPBs for industry-scale operations. Compared to existing technologies on microalgae dewatering such as filtration, floatation, flocculation, centrifugation etc., this innovation greatly reduces the energy, materials, and environmental costs, hence helping clear the bottleneck limiting the cost-effective production of algae-based biofuels.

Besides microalgae dewatering, directed phase separation and removal of water-borne microbes is a ubiquitous challenge for many industries, and the guiding concepts learnt from this study have far-reaching impacts on separation technology beyond biofuel production. For example, the production cost of microalgae-derived high-value diet supplements or cosmetic ingredients will be significantly reduced since microalgae dewatering is also the expensive step for these industries; the cost-effective algal coagulation method is highly desired for water purification since the removal of poisonous algal cells remains as a big challenge, at both municipal-plant and portable-device levels, and for cleaning up red tide or other algal booms that create havoc and disease in many parts of the world. From a wider perspective, capturing free-floating microbes highly efficiently is important to intercept biofilm propagation, which is critical for a wide range of applications ranging from mitigating microbe-influenced corrosion to the treatment of infectious diseases. Beyond working on living-cells, this study examined the colloidal stability in the presence of NPPBs, and opened a new door for the rational control of many industry-important colloidal suspensions (advanced ink, photonic crystals etc.). To date, the NSF support for this study helped produce 1 US patent, 8 peer-reviewed papers (one of which was featured on C&EN as a Research News), 2 papers in preparation, and 18 conference presentations at regional and national levels. The patent, publications and presentations supported by NSF helped disseminate our research findings to benefit society at large. This study also helped train 4 graduate students (one of which is a ROTC student, and two are female students), one medical student (female), 7 undergraduate and 4 high school students, most of which are from underrepresented groups.
